references: The optimization of a single design parameter Eğ¸E was studied inÂ [14, 15, 38, 39, 40], most of which assume full client participation and can be infeasible for large-scale on-device FL. A very recent work in [41] considered the optimization of both Eğ¸E and client selection for additive per-client costs. However, the cost of learning time in our problem is non-additive on a per-client basis, since different clients perform local model updates in parallel. In addition, the convergence bound used inÂ [41] (alsoÂ [13]) is for a primal-dual optimization algorithm, which is different from the commonly used FedAvg algorithm. The challenge in optimizing both Kğ¾K and Eğ¸E for cost minimization of FedAvg, which also distinguishes our work from the above, is the need to analytically connect the total cost with the control variables as well as with the convergence rate. The comparison of our work with the above related works is illustrated in TableÂ I, where we note that our optimization design is orthogonal to most works on resource allocation in the last column in TableÂ I and can be used together with those techniques to further reduce the cost.

references: We start by summarizing the basics of FL and its de facto algorithm FedAvg. Then, we introduce the scheduling strategy when applying FL in mobile edge networks with system heterogeneity. Finally, we present the cost optimization problem for FL tasks. We summarize all key notations in this paper in TableÂ II.

references: We first present the estimation process and results of A0B0subscriptğ´0subscriptğµ0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}} for the three experiment setups in TableÂ III. Figs.Â 4â€“6 compare the performance of our proposed solution of (Kâˆ—,Eâˆ—superscriptğ¾superscriptğ¸K^{*},\ E^{*}) with empirical optimal solution (KOPT,EOPTsubscriptğ¾OPTsubscriptğ¸OPTK_{\textnormal{OPT}},\ E_{\textnormal{OPT}}) and other (Kğ¾K, Eğ¸E) pairs141414The benchmark Eğ¸E and Kğ¾K are chosen to be either lager or smaller than the empirical optimal ones for comparison. for Prototype and Simulation Setups, respectively.151515We note that (Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*}, Eâˆ—superscriptğ¸E^{*}) are obtained by estimating the average value of A0B0subscriptğ´0subscriptğµ0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}}, whose estimation process is summarized in TableÂ III. Specifically, we empirically set two relatively high target losses Fasubscriptğ¹ğ‘F_{a} and Fbsubscriptğ¹ğ‘F_{b} with a few sampling pairs of (K,E)ğ¾ğ¸\left(K,E\right). Note that due to different learning tasks and statistical heterogeneity, the sampling range of Eğ¸E in Prototype Setup is larger than that in Simulation Setup. Then, we record the corresponding number of rounds for reaching Fasubscriptğ¹ğ‘F_{a} and Fbsubscriptğ¹ğ‘F_{b}, based on which we calculate the averaged estimation value of A0B0subscriptğ´0subscriptğµ0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}} using (22). The key observations are as follows.
